Letter of 1 July 1863
Letter of 27 June 1862
William B. Anderson's letter dated June 27, 1862 from Pittsburgh and addressed to his wife Louisa is written in ink on one side of a loose sheet of paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 9.0 inches tall (19 x 23 cm) and ruled with horizontal blue lines spaced .33 inches (0.8 cm) apart, except for a 1.5-inch (3.8 cm) unruled top margin. The left edge of the sheet is slightly ragged, while the other three edges are clean, suggesting that the sheet was torn from a notepad or bound notebook. It appears originally to have been folded once crosswise and twice lengthwise. At this writing, the ink appears brown and the paper off-white (cream). A .5-inch by .5-inch (1.3 x 1.3 cm) embossed printer's mark appears in the upper lefthand corner of the sheet, 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) from the top edge and .25 inches (0.6 cm) from the left edge. Although the mark is indistinct, its shape closely matches that of a distinct, similarly sized and positioned printer's mark on a letter dated July 1, 1863, which reads "MT HOLLY PAPER CO." (see illustrations). Texture? Stiffness? Watermarks? I will have to visit the RBML.

projectDesc.p:
Salutation from letter of 27 June 1862
In some ways, William B. Anderson's short letter of 27 June 1862 to his wife, Mary Louisa, typifies the twenty-one letters from William to Louisa that survive in the collection of the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University. It addresses three of the four broad topics about which he repeatedly writes to his wife during the summers of 1862, 1863, and 1864: managing domestic affairs and sustaining familial bonds when family members are separated for long periods by great distances; the rhetoric and logistics of mid-nineteenth-century correspondence; and the economic, logistical, and physical challenges of the riverboat business, especially on a waterway as critical as the Ohio River in the midst of the American Civil War (in other letters, Anderson also reflects more broadly on the uncertainties, vicissitudes, and suffering faced by civilians and soldiers alike in wartime).

However, this letter is also unique. All but two of the letters were written from Cincinnati, a thriving center of commerce on the Ohio River approximately halfway between its source at the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and its confluence with the Mississippi River a mile or so south of Cairo, Illinois. The remaining letter in the collection was written from St. Louis, Missouri—though Anderson mentions writing from Louisville, Kentucky and Nashville, Tennessee as well. This letter was written from Pittsburgh, William and Louisa's home town. Presumably, he had been visiting his family and had expected to leave Pittsburgh by the Friday in late June when he wrote the letter; he writes to inform his wife of a delay.

As the collection in general reveals, delays were common, caused variously by negotiations over freight, water levels on the river, mechanical difficulties, and various military complications. Arrangements regarding freight seem to have kept Anderson in Pittsburgh overnight on June 27. He wants to secure a full load before leaving Pittsburgh because he "cannot depend upon getting any freight below here." He takes the opportunity to ask Louisa to send down "the Can of milk and 2 jars of lard and my clothes and overcoat." The definite article stands out: the Can of milk. One wonders whether, in his habitual haste (on which he often blames poor spelling and handwriting), he has simply rushed off and forgotten these items, and Louisa has sent him a note asking what she should do with them. In any case, in his haste to send her instructions, he crosses out the next two lines of his letter and recomposes them. Characteristically, the life of a riverboat captain seems frenetic.

It is also worth noting that he arranges to convey a note to his wife via "some one on the Shore at Shousetown." While the Andersons clearly handled much of their correspondence through the U.S. mail (he mentions post offices several times, and the collection includes one stamped envelope), they often convey both messages and goods through intermediaries traveling by rail or river.

Anderson's closing request constitutes something of a refrain in the letters. He asks Louisa to call on a Mr. Russell (probably John Russell, a local merchant) in order to collect money owed him, noting that he must meet his obligations on the crew's upcoming payday. Aside from suggesting that riverboat captains had to watch their cash flow carefully, this request reminds us that Louisa played a key role not only in caring for the Anderson household, including their four children (a fifth would be born in 1865), but also in tending to their business interests. Though we have only William Anderson's side of the correspondence, the letters reveal many details of Louisa's everyday life as well.

It is Louisa, presumably, whom we have to thank for initially preserving the letters, probably for the very common, personal reasons to which David Levy alludes in Scrolling Forward: Making Sense of Documents in the Digital Age: "In the privacy of our own homes we are likely to hold on to any number of treasures: cards, letters, and notes written long ago, photographs, scrapbooks filled with mementoes from an earlier era. We can't throw them out, even if we can't say why. We may look at them rarely or not at all, yet still it is somehow comforting to know they are there. It's as if something of importance is embedded in their very substance. This has less to do with their information content per se than with the emotions they evoke and the personal relationships they signify and embody" (96–97). The Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University purchased the letters in part because they fit into a larger goal of acquiring materials that reveal the "common man's view of great events," and war letters are one focus of that larger effort (Smith). The collection as a whole, and the letter of 27 June 1862 more specifically, should also prove interesting to business historians and students of letter writing in American culture (Hewitt). The passing of time has made the everyday information in the letters newly valuable, though the letters also retain the power Levy speaks of to evoke the emotional fabric of everyday life, especially when it becomes frayed in the course of great events.
Hewitt, Elizabeth. Lecture to English 569C, Digital Media and English Studies. The Ohio State University. 6 Apr. 2006.
Levy, David M. Scrolling Forward: Making Sense of Documents in the Digital Age. New York: Arcade, 2001.
Smith, Geoffrey. Lecture to English 569C, Digital Media and English Studies. Rare Books and Manuscripts Library, The Ohio State University. 30 Mar. 2006.

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes.

Corrections and emendations in Anderson's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI <supplied> element.

The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such.
The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view.

refsDecl.p: The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl).

In general, this edition follows the Text Encoding Initiative's Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, XML-compatible edition P4. For more information about TEI P4, see http://www.tei-c.org/P4X/. To facilitate embedding or linking to image, audio, and video files, this edition supplements the Text Encoding Initiative's DTD by adding a URL attribute to the <xref> element and an MMID (i.e., Media Manager ID) attribute to the <pb> element. The values of the MMID attribute in <pb> elements and the file IDs in the URL attribute of <xref> elements that link to, or embed, image, audio, and video files contained in the Media Manager are generated by the Media Manager application.

bibl.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 27 June 1862.

div1.p: Anderson tells his wife that his boat's departure has been delayed by a day and asks her to send some food and clothes to him at the dock. He also expresses anxiety about whether his trip will be profitable and asks his wife to request some money from [John?] Russell to help cover an upcoming payday for his crew.
Previous letter 16 June 1862 Next letter 11 July 1862.

Yours Mailed 13th I got on my
arrival to the City this afternoon & was glad
to hear from you. I have been absent from
the City for a few days on a trip to Maysville
we are sill in Gov employ and I suppose we
will continue some time yet as there is no prospect
of water. I will have to be dissapointed in
my prospects of going home for while and
if you can come down I will be glad to
see you any time you can come you had better
not attempt to bring the children as they will
be to great a charge for you, although I should
be very happy to see them but you could not be
at liberty to go any place you might wish with
them and there is no reason why you could not
leave them in care of Mary McNamee and Julia
Porter for that time. You can make your own
arrangements about the children as I leave the
care of them altogether to you I think if you
will come down you had better come down you
had better not wait as long as next month
for fear the river will raise or if it dont
raise & should continue to fall we might be sent
down below. this is my advise to you will be
for you to come by the Steubenville route and
leave Pittsburgh at one Oclock or there abouts
and when you get on board you tell the
Conductor that you want to take the sheeping
Car which they take in tow at Steubenville
and that will cost you 50 cts extra that train
arrives at the Dayton & Hamilton Depot at about
5 or 6 oclock A.M. the ticket office is on
Liberty Street near the Canal on the left hand
side of the street it might be that John
will come down with you and that would
be better as I think he has acted very foolish
for I have to pay 5$ each per day for Pilots
and he might just as well had 200$ dollars
while he has been at home as not if you should
come down or have any chance to send me
that pair of Blue pants & belt down I would
like to have them as my Pants are getting thin
and I don’t want to spend any money I can
help. I have not seen your mother for
2 or three weeks I may see her in a few
days if you come let me know a few days
before you come when to be on the look out
for you.

Tell Old Man Walsh that I will take 12
dolls for that Heifer & for him to sell the Hay
and divide the money I think hay will be very
High in the spring but I suppose he wants his
share of the money he can do as he thinks
best about it. That Bank notice you spoke
about I made arrangements with Holmes
& Sons Brokers to pay all my notes that will
fall due I told Mr Wright to use what Money
was deposited at Holmes & Sons belonging to the Boat
to Pay Notes & when that ran out to use what
I had there which is sufficient to pay all claims
that may fall due for a while I will look
for a letter from you soon and will be
pleased to hear of you making satisfa
=ctory arrangements to come and see me
as it seems utterly impossibly for me to
leave for the present I am to settle up
our business here up till the 15 of this Mo
this or next week and then I will find out
what I am making but one thing I do
know is this that I am doing as well as I
want to with a boat my share of the proffits
and wages is at least 40 dolls per day and that
is not bad but keep it to yourself. I will stop
as the mail Closes at 8 Oclock this evening I
will write soon again but write immediately
and give me all the news and take good
Care of yourself and the children and kiss
all of them for me and tell them to be good

Excuse Haste & Bad writing as there is a constant
taklking and fun in the Hall
